title: Bearish Divergence Flashes Warning for Semiconductor Stocks
text: What is a bearish divergence, and what does it tell us about price momentum? Here we will review the chart of the semiconductor ETF (SMH) and discuss why future textbooks on technical analysis will feature this chart.

title: Which Key Sectors Can Support the Stock Market?
text: Wednesday was another disappointing day for the market as many short-term buyers from Tuesday got flushed out in the move lower.  However, with a second down day should we be worried about a potential correction or is the market still holding its main support?

title: The Markets Continue Consolidating (Technically Speaking For 3/3)
text: US manufacturing is going strong. The ADP Report was soft.

title: Market Recap: Wednesday, March 3: Stocks close at trading session lows
text: Stocks traded mixed Wednesday after sliding a day earlier, as investors weighed optimism over widespread post-pandemic business reopenings against concerns over economic overheating. The Dow rose while the S&P 500 fell in afternoon trading, while Treasury yields resumed advancing across the curve.

title: Cramer: On the cusp of a post-Covid boom, money managers want reopening plays
text: "We've reached the point in the business cycle where the companies with the worst numbers suddenly have the best stocks," the "Mad Money" host said.

title: Jim Cramer: This rotation ends when the economy hits a wall
text: "In the meantime, we've got a glut of tech stocks and a shortage of cyclicals," the "Mad Money" host said.

title: Companies with the worst numbers suddenly have the best stocks, Jim Cramer says
text: "We're on the cusp of a post-Covid boom that now looks to be pushed forward happening much sooner than expected," CNBC's Jim Cramer said.

title: Tech 'rollover' is a major buying opportunity: Oppenheimer's top strategist

title: JP Morgan's Gabriela Santos: There's still time to rotate from growth to value stocks
text: Gabriela Santos, JP Morgan asset management, joins 'Closing Bell' to give her take on whether it's too late for investors to transition from growth to value stocks as we see the big tech stocks drop in today's market.

text: Jeff Degraff, Renaissance Macro Research, joins 'Closing Bell' to discuss the state of the markets. He also says the markets are being under-appreciative of energy stocks, which have more to run.

title: The Dow Fell 121 Points Because Higher Rates Wrecked Growth Stocks
text: A spike in the 10-year Treasury yield sandbagged the standard-bearers of large-cap growth, including Netflix and Tesla.

title: Will Bond Yields Fastest Rise In 50 Years Rattle Markets?
text: The waterfall decline of bond yields (and interest rates) has been met with an equally steep rally. In fact, the 10-Year US Treasury bond yield is up 131% in 45 weeks, making it the biggest rally in 50 years!

title: Chips, vaccines, and 'techno autocracies' — Why Big Tech and Biden are going to be friends
text: Hello, and welcome to this Wednesday's edition of the Insider Tech newsletter, where we break down the biggest news in tech. I'm your host Alexei Oreskovic. title: Dow sours before the close, Nasdaq whacked as rising yield rates sink big tech
text: 4:10pm: Industrials end in the red after mostly positive day The Dow ended Wednesday down 121 points, 0.4%, at 31,270 after spending most of the session in the green. The Nasdaq lost 361 points, 2.7%, to 12,998, and the S&P 500 dropped 51 points, 1.3%, to finish at 3,820.

title: The Fed: Fed's Harker sees no interest-rate hikes until 2023
text: Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker said Wednesday he doesn't see the central bank hiking its policy rate until 2023.

title: Tech stocks plummet as surging Treasury yields rock market
text: The value rotation continued on Wednesday as rising Treasury yields cut into bullishness around growth stocks. Tech giants and other momentum names tumbled after ADP's monthly employment report showed February job growth missing expectations. The US added 117,000 private payrolls last month, the report said. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg had anticipated a 200,000-payroll gain.

title: U.S. stocks tumble into the close as rising bond yields weigh on market

text: Bond yields have been higher than stock dividend yields for most of history, but it hasn't prevented stocks from rising most of the way.

title: Economic Report: Fed's Beige Book finds only modest improvement in economy
text: U.S. economic activity expanded modesty from January until mid-February, according to the Federal Reserve's latest report on economic conditions known as the Beige Book.

title: The Fed: If market thinks we're not living up to inflation targets that's ‘a problem,' says Fed's Evans
text: Chicago Fed President Charles Evans said Wednesday that any doubt in markets about the Fed's commitment to get inflation higher would be a 'problem' and said investors should understand he would even be comfortable with inflation at a 3% rate

title: Federal Reserve: Economic activity expanded modestly

title: Understanding SOFR
text: In June 2023, the U.S. dollar London Inter-Bank Offered Rate (LIBOR) will likely be discontinued. Secured Overnight Funding Rate (SOFR) is expected to replace LIBOR in a variety of financial products as benchmark reference rates.

title: Why Rising Bond Yields Needn't Dampen the Equity Party
text: Last week, equities tumbled as Treasury yields surged, but rising bond yields don't always lead to long periods of under-performance for stocks. What's pivotal in this equation is for investors to assess why bond yields are rising in the first place, and whether the scenario boils down to one of two examples.

title: Asset Class Scoreboard: February 2021
text: Up 15% for the year already, I think we'll be talking about commodity performance for a good portion of 2021. Managed Futures are holding down second place with a good start to the year in a great turnaround from the first month of 2021.

title: The Opposite Of 2008
text: In 2008, the US housing market - together with a Fed that thought the subprime crisis was "contained" - delivered the mother of all deflationary shocks to the global economy. In 2021, the US housing market - together with a Fed that thinks inflationary pressures are "transitory" - risks delivering the mother of all inflationary shocks.

title: Will The Markets Continue To Rally In March?

title: 5 Important Charts to Watch in May 2019

title: US benchmarks stay mixed after private payrolls for February miss expectations
text: 12:45: Dow outperforms the broader market The Dow was up 54 points, 0.2%, to 31,446 at midday. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq dropped 192 points, 1.4%, to 13,168, and the S&P 500 slipped 18 points, 0.5%, to 3,852.

title: Recent short squeezes indicate excess liquidity: Neuberger Berman CIO
text: Joseph Amato, CIO at Neuberger Berman, joins "Squawk on the Street" to discuss the volatility in names like Rocket Companies and GameStop, and what it means for the market.

title: In One Chart: The stock market's most sensitive sector says cycle isn't anywhere close to turning
text: Consumer-discretionary stocks are the most sensitive to the market cycle, and right now they're giving no indication that the cycle is about to turn, says one of Wall Street's most closely followed technical analysts.

title: Larry Summers And Stimulus, Manufacturing And Inflation
text: Larry Summers has been warning about too much stimulus - he thinks $1.9 trillion is too much - because it might well bring inflation back. Manufacturing output is soaring and significantly adding to inflationary pressures in the sector.
